 Co-Founder/CEO Continuous Solutions March 2014  – Present (1 year 6 months) Portland, OR Co-founded by Dr. Nir Vaks and Dr. Nyah Zarate, Continuous Solutions LLC (based in the beautiful city of Portland, OR) is a think tank with a concentration of high-level expertise in the R&D of disruptive energy efficient technologies. Currently, Continuous Solutions is involved in the design of dynamic power-electronic-based electromechanical systems such as those found in vehicles, aircraft, ships, terrestrial power, and spacecraft applications. The company is currently involved in the development of a number of projects including patented high-efficiency, low-cost, Permanent Magnet (PM) based generator to fulfill an initial order of $20 million to provide reliable, inexpensive electricity to villages in rural Asia. In addition, Continuous Solutions is developing a revolutionary direct-drive in-wheel hub motor for high-torque low-speed Electric Vehicles to improve fuel economy, improve vehicle handling, and reduce overall system complexity and cost. Continuous Solutions has extensive knowledge in the area of Smart Grid, Micro Grid technologies, as well as Renewable energy integration for ESS of rural areas. Process Development Engineer Intel Corporation June 2013  –  April 2014  (11 months) Hillsboro, OR Process Development Engineer at Intel Corporation in the Logic Technology Design Group. Her role at Intel entails project management of employees in many role levels, meeting production goals, coordination between departments and technical development. 
 
Other responsibilities in her role as a Process Development Engineer at Intel was to define and establishe flow, procedures, and equipment configuration for microprocessor fabrication and establish process control systems and sustain the process through volume ramp.  
 
She led teams to drive improvements on the quality, reliability, cost, yield, process stability/capability of devices. In this team environment she took a leadership role to develop solutions for process matching and work optimization. Research Assistant Purdue University August 2008  –  April 2013  (4 years 9 months) West Lafayette, IN Nyah Zarate, obtained her Ph.D. in the area Particulate Design and behavior characterization at the CHE department in Purdue University. As a research assistant, Nyah was responsible for multiple design, modeling, and simulation projects in the areas of Powder Technology, Particulate design, and manufacturing of Power material. In her Ph.D. dissertation titled “Multiscale Modeling of Particulate Systems by Incorporating Particle Roughness”, Powder behavior during solids handling, such as in the pharmaceutical, food, and personal care industries, is controlled to a large degree by the adhesion characteristics of the powder’s particulate ensemble characteristics. Key physical properties of a particulate system, such as size, geometry, composition, and surface roughness, generally control the particle adhesion. Regardless of the application, there is a general need to control and understand the interactions at the particle-substrate and particle-particle interfaces at micro- to nano-meter scales in order to predict powder behavior and increase efficiency during the industrial processes of solids. Nyah developed and experimentally validated a model to predict adhesion force calculation of particles-surfaces interactions. The model is able to represent particle-surface interactions accurately and with greater robustness by accounting for surface roughness developed Matlab based Discrete Element Method routines. 
 PhD NSF fellow Engineering Research Center of Structured Organic Particulate Systems (ERC-SOPS) Purdue University December 2009  –  December 2012  (3 years 1 month) Purdue University C-SOPS focuses on understanding basic aspects of pharmaceutical and manufacturing science where lack of knowledge has been a fundamental barrier to the development of and manufacture of newer dosage forms. These programs range from the formation and characterization of particles and particulate dispersions to the science needed for the development of manufacturing systems operating under closed loop control.  
 
Nyah worked in a cross-disciplinary team of engineers and scientists as well as industry leaders to improve the way pharmaceuticals, foods and agriculture products are manufactured. C-SOPS will focus on advancing the scientific foundation for the optimal design of SOPS with advanced functionality while developing the methodologies for their active control and manufacturing. Design of Experiments Nanomaterials Thin Films Aspen Plus TEM Electrochemistry Laboratory Surface Chemistry Heterogeneous Catalysis Nanotechnology R&D Thermodynamics Labview Optical Microscopy Process Simulation NMR See 35+     See less Education Purdue University Doctor of Philosophy (PhD),  Chemical Engineering 2008  – 2013 This is the first study to relate statistical functions of surface roughness to an in-depth examination of particle adhesion force distributions for elastic micron-sized randomly rough particulate systems. The results have significant impact on multi-scale modeling approaches, emphasizing the effect of particle surface topography on adhesion force can impact the assembly of particles, and showing it is not sufficient to model particles as ideal spheres with single point adhesion forces. Using statistical functions to describe the effect of roughness on adhesion can open up the possibility of including such details in macroscopic particle assembly models. Activities and Societies:  AiCHE ,  Purdue Chemical Engineering Graduate Student Organization ,  Women's Initiative Program ,  Purdue Latino Association Purdue University M.S.,  Chemical Engineering 2008  – 2010 State of the art techniques were used and developed to study the effect of capillary condensation under humid conditions using atomic force microscopy (AFM) with α-lactose monohydrate (ALM), one of the most common pharmaceutical excipients used in formulation and silicon nitride as a model particles, against process surfaces.  
 
Phase imaging was used to measure the change in surface moisture on stainless steel and Perpspex® as relative humidity was increased by 10% increments between 15 and 65%. For hydrophilic stainless steel, the low energy (high moisture) regions correlated closely with the topology of the surface roughness. Liquid accumulated in the valleys as RH levels increased and reversible adhesion force profile between silicon nitride and stainless steel increased from 3 nN to 30 nN due to capillary bridging. Summary I am currently a Process Development Engineer at Intel Corporation's Portland Technology Development division in Hillsboro, OR. I work to improve and perfect semiconductor processes for the 14 nm and 10 nm technology nodes using advanced wafer inspection tools. In addition, I research and develop new wafer inspection tools for future technology nodes. I finished a PhD in Physics at the Georgia Institute of Technology studying epitaxial graphene on silicon carbide (SiC), focusing on the growth and electronic properties of nanostructured epitaxial graphene. 
 
Specialties: Statistical Process Control (SPC), Desing of Experiments (DoE), Surface Science, Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Optics Summary I am currently a Process Development Engineer at Intel Corporation's Portland Technology Development division in Hillsboro, OR. Primary responsibilities involve wafer inspection tool data collection and communication with process integration. Data collection volume is solidly in the 'Big data' regime, with all of the associated challenges (capture, analysis, curation, sharing, etc). Additional responsibilities include researching new applications for current wafer inspection tools, improving the capabilities of current-generation inspection tools, and development new inspection tools for future technology nodes. Graduate Research Scientist Georgia Institute of Technology September 2007  –  May 2013  (5 years 9 months) Atlanta, GA Research & Leadership Experience; Developed and managed undergraduate and graduate students in a laboratory setting. 
 
Organized weekly graphene journal club meetings for undergraduate and graudate students in the greater Atlanta area, with funding from the National Science Foundation. 
 
Studied high temperature (up to 1700 C) decomposition of silicon carbide, which results in surface layers of graphene (a single layer or few layers of graphite). 
 
Designed and constructed a novel ultra-high vacuum furnace for graphene growth. 
 
Performed scanning tunneling microscopy to find and characterize `nanoribbons' of graphene. 
 
Developed a method for measuring the number of graphene layers on a surface. 
 
Optimized a hydrogen etching process for silicon carbide using a FirstNano CVD furnace. Developed a technique for creating graded/stepped silicon dioxide films on silicon.

Summary Manuel is a Class Test (CT) Module Process Development Engineer with Intel Corporation that focuses on the development, optimization, qualification and deployment of robust microelectronic packages test equipment and processes. In 2011 Manuel’s work included new equipment, tooling, and process characterization work. In 2012, he will be working on transferring those processes to Intel factories all over the world. 
Manuel is interested in developing his abilities in mechanical failure and design, microelectronics packages thermal analysis, manufacturing and processing activities, and material science activities. Specialties:Results-driven with practical experience in thermo-mechanical design and failure analysis. Expertise in solid mechanics and advanced materials characterization techniques; Significant work in finite element modeling for failure analysis, and structure reliability of microstructures, mechanical parts and full assemblies; Expirience with numerical simulation and computational mechanics; Excellent written and verbal comunication skills, authorship of published work; Team environment dynamic.
